Posts.Content: You are most welcome!!!  My Oncologist has me taking 1200 mg of Calcium and 2000 of D3 daily, too.  Thanks for your wishes for good health!!  I just received a diagnosis of a need for a 3rd round of fighting on March 2nd.  I begin radiation tomorrow, have a biospy on Monday to learn if this is a metastises of the breast cancer or something new, and a PET scan on Tuesday.  The Dr says if the cancer doesn't show up anywhere else, the prognosis is good.  We should know more by midweek next week.  The Medical Oncologist will make a plan for combating the cancer after the tests results are in.  He took me off the Aromasin.  I think it's because I can't be on it when I start chemo again.  GOD bless you on your journey and may you NEVER have a recurrence!!!
Posts.Title: Anyone taking EXEMESTRANE 25 mg?

Posts.Content: Hi EvWallace, I'm glad your rash has cleared up.  I am taking Exemestrane 25 mg.  I was put on in it seven months ago when I had a recurrence.  I had been on Anastrozole for 4 years.  Since it was a local recurrence and no metastasis, the Oncologist said the Anastrozole had helped.  It is difficult for me to decide if the Exemestrane is causing fatigue and or bone pain due to the chemo and radiation side effects.  The Oncologist put me on B12-1mg due to another issue which seems to help with the fatigue.
Posts.Title: Anyone taking EXEMESTRANE 25 mg?

Posts.Content: THANKS for your post-Babysteps4me.  I was diagnosed with stage one breast cancer in 2009, had a mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy.  All nodes were clean. Testing was done to find a recurrence risk which came back at only 7.5%. There was no chemo or radiation as the Drs said with the low risk of recurrence, the mastectomy and taking the medication, they couldn't say that I would benefit from further treatment.  I was put on Tamoxifen until 2010 when it was recommended that I have a hysterectomy so I could switch to Arimidex as the fibroids I had were changing with the Tamoxifen and there was a small risk of developing uterine cancer.  I took Arimidex 4 years and had a recurrence in 2014. The Oncologist said the Arimidex worked as this was a local recurrence and not a metastasis. I underwent chemo, radiation and surgery this past year.  I've been experiencing lower back pain and am to have a bone scan and MRI tomorrow morning.  Reading your post has given me hope that should this be another battle, to keep fighting.  THANKS!!! GOD bless you!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to Bone Treatments

Posts.Content: THANKS for your post-Babysteps4me.  I was diagnosed with stage one breast cancer in 2009, had a mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy.  All nodes were clean. Testing was done to find a recurrence risk which came back at only 7.5%. There was no chemo or radiation as the Drs said with the low risk of recurrence, the mastectomy and taking the medication, they couldn't say that I would benefit from further treatment.  I was put on Tamoxifen until 2010 when it was recommended that I have a hysterectomy so I could switch to Arimidex as the fibroids I had were changing with the Tamoxifen and there was a small risk of developing uterine cancer.  I took Arimidex 4 years and had a recurrence in 2014. The Oncologist said the Arimidex worked as this was a local recurrence and not a metastasis. I underwent chemo, radiation and surgery this past year.  I've been experiencing lower back pain and am to have a bone scan and MRI tomorrow morning.  Reading your post has given me hope that should this be another battle, to keep fighting.  THANKS!!! GOD bless you!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to Bone Treatments

Posts.Content: Someone had to be wrong and I pray it was those who said it was cancer during chemo.  I so hope that your report is that it is a benign tumor.  The waiting for the path report can be difficult for sure.  Did you have surgery when you were diagnosed?  I'm assuming you did since you had chemo.  My experience with my Surgeon has been that he has been right both times he's done a biopsy on me.  May your Surgeon be correct, too!!
Posts.Title: Axillary lymph node

Posts.Content: No, I'm not saying that if it is painful that means it is cancer.  No!! No!!!  I just was saying the spot I had in the lymph node felt tight and I thought it was scar tissue.  It was a recurrence.  I underwent chemo, radiation and surgery in 2014.  I am now being evaluated by Drs at Cancer Treatment Centers of America for a 2nd opinion, as local Drs now say there are metastases to the bones.  I am told that breast cancer with metastases to the bones patients can live with it as a chronic diseases would be treated.  I've read of patients who have lived 4-16 years since being diagnosed with bone metastases.   The thing is to stay positive and don't let yourself be driven by fear because then, the cancer steals your life that you could be enjoying.  GOD bless you and may your report be good news, I pray!!!
Posts.Title: Axillary lymph node

Posts.Content: Hi emc68, While I'm not a perfect match with your specifics, I did want to respond.  I had breast cancer in 2009, at which time a sentinel node biopsy was done with all nodes taken being negative for cancer.  I had a total mastectomy on that side.  In 2014, it felt as if the scar tissue from the surgery was drawing and with doing stretching exercises, it was relieved. It was soft to the touch.  A few days later it was time for a routine followup with the Oncologist.  When he pressed hard against the spot he decided to have an ultrasound, which led to a biopsy and a recurrence diagnosis.  All axillary lymph nodes were removed and the path report confirmed the diagnosis.
Posts.Title: Axillary lymph node

Posts.Content: The first time around was Invasive Ductal Carcinoma.  The second time there was a recurrence on the side where the mastectomy had been done.  A sentinel node biopsy was done the first time around and only 3 lymph nodes were removed which were all negative-no cancer.  The reucrrence was in a lymph node.  The Surgeon told me that had they done the traditional lymph node dissection they have done for many years instead of the sentinel node one, they would have caught it then.  As I told him, we can't go back, so we go from where we are.   I'm thankful your pap test showed no changes last week.  I think the waiting would be harder than having the hysterectomy for me.  We are all different, of course, and each have to decide what course we will follow.   I, too, get copies of all reports and yes, they do have errors sometimes.  Any time humans are involved there is a potential for error.  We even ask to see the film studies as well.  I take a list of questions with me to my Doctor's visits.  I'm blessed with good Drs who welcome my questions and said they wish their other patients did the same.   My biggest issue with non traditional treatments, although I know the traditional ones can bring harm and may not do what they are being used to do, is that I had a sister who refused non traditional treatments out of fear and spent money chasing after a cure and a few days past a year, she passed.  The Dr had told her without treatment she would live about a year.  She even saw a "Dr," who did magnetic treatments and told her she was cured if she'd only believe after the last treatment, while there was a tumor on her neck that was ever growing.  She suffered with that tumor and all the horrible things that went with it until the day she left us.  Thank GOD, we were with her.  I had finished chemo and went to be with her on Friday after the last chemo and stayed with her until she passed on Monday morning.   Thanks for your prayers and I do pray that you are blessed as well!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I learned yesterday that the FDA has approved a drug called Palbociclib (Brand name- Ibrance), that when taken with Letrolzole (Femara), more than doubles the months of progression free survival (10.2 with Letrozole alone to 20.2 with Palbociclib added)  and the number of progression free survival events from 59% to 41%.   I will discuss this with the Oncologist on the next visit as well as continue research on my own.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the information you shared!!!  I am, by GOD's grace, going to stay positive and love, joy and peace are wonderful states to live in!!!   I appreciate all the support and by HIS grace, I will take a step at the time and trust HIS direction on the journey!!  Thanks again for all your information.   GOD bless you!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I am SO SO SORRY that your Mom has been diagnosed with stage 4 breast cancer.  I highly recommend the site breastcancer.org  I used it many, many times during my journey of almost 6 years now. I was positive for Estrogen receptors-meaning Estrogen acts as fuel for the cancer I had.  Triple positive means the cancer is fueled by estrogen, progesteron and the HER 2 gene is the information I have been given.  Femara is a drug used to treat the estrogen recptor aspect.  Herceptin is used in the treatment of the HER 2 gene aspect. breastcancer.org /symptoms/diagnosis/hormone_status" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.breastcancer.org /symptoms/diagnosis/hormone_statu  This web site has a lot of information about breast cancer.  This is a link that talks about hormone receptors. I would say you also need a physician who is willing to answer your questions.  You might want to ask if there is a Nurse Navigator at the treatment center who can help you with information and resources.  May your Mom be blessed with many, many more years!!!  Stage 4 patients today have a much better outlook than in days gone by.  I've read of those who are 13-20 years past a stage 4 diagnosis.  May your Mom be blessed to be one who is as well.   I'm beginning the third round of fighting, with this being the first time it has been somewhere besides the original location.  I'm thus staged at 4 as well.   GOD bless!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I learned yesterday that the FDA has approved a drug called Palbociclib (Brand name- Ibrance), that when taken with Letrolzole (Femara), more than doubles the months of progression free survival (10.2 with Letrozole alone to 20.2 with Palbociclib added)  and the number of progression free survival events from 59% to 41%.   I will discuss this with the Oncologist on the next visit as well as continue research on my own.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I was initially diagnosed in 2009 with early stage breast cancer.  I had a mastectomy, began taking Tamoxifen and after genetic testing to determine risk of recurrence was told that there wasn't proof that patients with my situation were benefited by chemo and the Dr said, "I can't push you towards chemo."  I was told since there had been a mastectomy, no radiation was needed.  Eleven months after beginning Tamoxifen and my Gynecologist watching some fibroids in my uterus, a complete hysterectomy was recommended so I could be put on Arimidex and remove the risk of uterine cancer.  This was in April, 2010.  In January 2014 there was a recurrence.  I underwent chemo, surgery to remove the implant I had from the first mastectomy and all lymph nodes on that side, plus removal of the breast, and took 35 r4adiation treatments.  The radiaton was the last form of treatment and it was finished on Oct 31, 2014.  In early January of this year, I began experiencing lower back pain after being released to use my treadmill.  After using it Mon., Wed., and Fri., I was in pain and walking was difficult.  I just  thought I'd overdone the exercising.  I stopped using the treadmill.  A week or so later, I had really tough pain in the hip area.  When that was gone, I began hurting in the entire area of the hip.  I thought this was all connected to a fall I'd had after surgery last August.  I went to my Chiropractor on February 20th.  He took some x-rays, saw something he was concerned about and sent me to my Oncologist.  A MRI and a bone scan were ordered.  I went this past Monday and learned that there is cancer in my tailbone, sacrum and a tumor in one leg with a smaller tumor in the other leg-both up where the leg joins the body.  I am to begin radiation tomorrow-Thursday, have a biopsy of the smaller tumor in my leg on Monday, have a PET scan on Tuesday and was told to call the Oncologist 24 hours after the PET scan for the results.  The Oncologist will then plan the path as to chemo/medical treatment.   Having said all of this, I would like to know if there is anyone who has had a breast cancer MET to the bone.  I've read about some patients who are 7-13 years out from a bone MET.  THANKS!!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: THANK you for your encouraging message about relatives who were given an expected time to lose the fight against cancer, yet are still here!!  WONDERFUL!!!  I'm thankful for GOD's blessings on them!!!  I will, by GOD's grace, keep a positive attitude and do my best to enjoy every day.  I think one thing others don't realize who haven't had cancer is that they are susceptible to dying as one fighting cancer because on one is promised the next breath.  Enjoying our days is so very important!!  Thanks, again!!!  GOD bless your Aunt!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: So sorry that the carrot juice didn't work in your case and that the cancer grew.  I hope that you will continue to look for methods of fighting and not give up hope!!!   GOD bless you!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the information you shared!!!  I am, by GOD's grace, going to stay positive and love, joy and peace are wonderful states to live in!!!   I appreciate all the support and by HIS grace, I will take a step at the time and trust HIS direction on the journey!!  Thanks again for all your information.   GOD bless you!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I would say the main thing is not to panic.  Stage 4 sounds scarey, but it isn't like it used to be.  I just met a lady at Cancer Treatment Center of America (CTCA) whose initial diagnosis was Stage 4 and it was in both breasts, her liver and she was told her brain.  However, CTCA said it wasn't in her brain and she is being treated.  I was told of a patient who was initially diagnosed with Stage 4 with bone, lung and liver metastases who is SIXTEEN years out since the diagnosis.  Make sure she has a medical team who is ready to do the best for her as to fighting.  If you will research, you will find that there are LOTS of women with Stage 4 who have been living and are still living years past that diagnosis.  There is a web link that is women with Stage 4.  It is mbcn.org You might want to go there and read some of the stories of ladies who have Stage 4.  GOD bless you and your sister!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I'm thankful that the carrot juice worked for the lady in New Zealand and for you as well!  Thanks for your best wises, too!!  May neither of you ever have a recurrence again.  :)
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I also agree that if carrot juice cured all cancers, there wouldn't be enough carrots for everyone.  I also add, that if it works for anyone, I'm happy for them.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: THANKS for this very encouraging news!!  I pray that I am blessed like your friend's Mom was blessed!!!  I agree that we must keep a positive attitude and by the LORD's help, I keep hope and faith.  Yes, our appointment with death is real for us all (humans), some of us have had the wake up call.  It does give a whole different view of what is precious and valuable!!  GOD bless you!!!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Mets to the Bones

Posts.Content: I wish to thank you for your words of encouragment.  Indeed, GOD is with me or I couldn't make the trip.  HE is my STRENGTH and my COURAGE every moment of ever day!!!  It's great to read that you are 11 years out!!  Hallelujah!!  Praise the Holy Name of the LORD!!!  GOD bless you, Tinkerbell!!!
Posts.Title: Xeloda and fatigue

Posts.Title: Xeloda and fatigue

Posts.Content: While I am a person of faith and know that GOD has been with me through my first and second battle with breast cancer, I think Daisy is going a bit too far with giving advice to your Mom about something as serious as breast cancer.  I would say, unless GOD speaks directly to your Mom-not through Daisy-she should follow up with the Oncologist.  I don't believe that it was proper for Daisy to tell her to hide it from her family.  With your being pregnant, this is stress that you don't need.  I'm a firm believer that if GOD does something, it isn't to be hidden.  I also believe that when HE does a healing, the tests will confirm that healing.  Denial can be a part of the whole cancer diagnosis reaction and Daisy needs to be careful that she isn't taking your Mom's life into her hands by giving her this advice.  If your relationship with your Mom is where you can, maybe just sit down and discuss your concerns for her out of your love for her.  While you can't make your Mom followup, you and your family can try to speak to her of your love and concern for her and pray she will listen.  It isn't an easy road to make the journey for cancer treatments and sometimes due to the fear of that journey, denial seems easier.  May GOD bless you, your family and especially, your Mom!!!
Posts.Title: My mom was just diagnosed with breast cancer.

Posts.Content: You might want to speak with your Dr about using Aloe Vera Gel.  It is a thick gel that soothes burns and is a natural product made from the Aloe Vera plant.
Posts.Title: Radiation Burns

Posts.Content: A great site for research is breastcancer.org  Type What is Mastectomy? in the searchbox and you should see an article about different types of mastectomies and who normally is a candidate for each specific type of procedure.  Here is a small portion of the article having to do with simple mastectomy.   Simple" or "total" mastectomy Simple or total mastectomy concentrates on the breast tissue itself: The surgeon removes the entire breast. The surgeon does not perform axillary lymph node dissection(removal of lymph nodes in the underarm area). Sometimes, however, lymph nodes are occasionally removed because they happen to be located within the breast tissue taken during surgery. No muscles are removed from beneath the breast. Simple MastectomyLarger Version Who usually gets simple or total mastectomy? A simple or total mastectomy is appropriate for women with multiple or large areas of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and for women seeking prophylactic mastectomies — that is, breast removal in order to prevent any possibility of breast cancer occurring.
Posts.Title: has anyone had simple mastecomy after reoccuring breast cancer
